property.name: text
property.value: The AudioReader reads an input PSK signal and executes a sequence of signal analyses to determine the carrier, baud rate, and number of phase states. The resampler computes an unknown number of output samples, preventing static scheduling of the toplevel model. Since the amount of processed data changes, the PhaseStatesEstimator model cannot be a synchronous dataflow model. In this model the PhaseStatesEstimator is quasi-statically scheduled using the Parameterized Synchronous Dataflow domain.

property.name: text
property.value: A model of a blind communication receiver that illustrates the use of the parameterized synchronous dataflow domain.

svg.text: Author: Stephen Neuendorffer, Data and Algorthms provided by Southwest Research Institute

property.name: text
property.value: This model estimates the carrier of the incoming signal and converts the signal down to base band by multiplying it with the estimated carrier signal.

property.name: text
text
property.value: These actors subsample the incoming signal according to the given baud rate.

property.name: text
property.value:
This model generates a sequence of boolean values that are true at the given baud rate and false otherwise. A true value is output on the first execution.
Note: This model generates one sample at a time in order to improve interactivity of signal plots for large input datasets.

entity.name: SampleDelay
entity.doc: The sdf delay actor, which behaves as an initial token on an arc.

property.name: text
property.value: This model estimates the number of phase states of the incoming resampled signal by computing a histogram of the phase differences and applying some thresholds. In this model reconfiguration of the inputCount parameter (and the number of samples consumed by the histogram) occurs just before the beginning of each execution of the schedule. Hence, the model is locally synchronous and can be quasi-statically scheduled.

property.name: text
property.value: This model plots the phase difference between successive input samples. Plotting the phase difference for communication systems such as this often results in more meaningful plots than the absolute phase, since there are inevitable estimation errors.
